'At-will employment' is a doctrine of American law that defines an employment
relationship in which either party can immediately terminate the relationship
at any time with or without any advance warning, Jay Shepherd, Firing At
Will: A Manager's Guide (New York: Apress Media, 2011), 3-4. and with no
subsequent liability, provided there was no express contract for a definite
term governing the employment relationship and that the employer does not
belong to a collective bargaining group (i.e., has not recognized a union).
Under this legal doctrine:



In a decision largely reaffirming employers' rights under the at-will doctrine
taken in October 5, 2000, the Supreme Court of California explained:



Several statutory and judge-made exceptions to the doctrine exist, especially if
unlawful discrimination is involved regarding the termination of an employee.
However, in the USA at least, such exceptions are often considered to be
contentious; Tyler Cowen and Alex Tabarrok have argued, in their macroeconomics
textbook, that employers become more reluctant to hire employees if they are
uncertain about their ability to immediately fire them. Tyler Cowen and Alex
Tabarrok, Modern Principles: Macroeconomics (New York: Worth Publishers, 2010),
202. In a 1992 study, the RAND Corporation concluded that imposing
exceptions to at-will employment resulted in a long-term drop in aggregate
employment of two to five percent. Timothy Sandefur, The Right to Earn a
Living: Economic Freedom and the Law (Washington, D.C., Cato Institute, 2010),
235â236.

The doctrine of at-will employment has been criticized as predicated upon flawed
assumptions about the inherent distribution of power and information in the employee-
employer relationship, John W. Budd, Employment with a Human Face: Balancing
Efficiency, Equity, and Voice (Ithaca: Cornell University Press, 2004),
86â88. as well as for its brutal harshness upon employees. Clyde W.
Summers, Employment At Will in the United States: The Divine Right of Employers,
3 U. Pa. J. Lab. & Emp. L. 65 (2000). However, scholars in the field of
law and economics such as Professors Richard A. Epstein Roger Blanpain,
Susan Bison-Rapp, William R. Corbett, Hilary K. Josephs, & Michael J. Zimmer,
The Global Workplace: International and Comparative Employment Law â Cases and
Materials (New York: Cambridge University Press, 2007), 101â102. and
Richard Posner Richard Posner, Overcoming Law (Cambridge: Harvard University
Press, 1995), 305â311. credit employment at will as a major factor
underlying the strength of the U.S. economy. At-will employment has also been
stressed as a significant reason for the success of Silicon Valley as an entrepreneur-
friendly environment. Alan Hyde, Working in Silicon Valley: Economic and
Legal Analysis of a High-Velocity Labor Market (Armonk, NY: M.E. Sharpe, 2003),
xvi and 92â97. Hyde's book explores "how high-velocity work practices contribute
to economic growth," including and especially the dominant American high-
velocity work practice of at-will employment.

At-will employment disclaimers are a staple of employee handbooks in the United
States. It is common for employers to define what at-will employment means,
explain that an employeeâs at-will status cannot be changed except in a writing
signed by the company president (or chief executive), and require that an
employee sign an acknowledgment of his or her at-will status.
